sub_topic: The chaotic dynamics of the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction
message_1:
A researcher observed the concentration of bromate ions in a Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction and collected the following data:
t | [BrO3] (M)
--- | ---
0 | 0.08
10 | 0.1
20 | 0.16
30 | 0.2
40 | 0.18
50 | 0.12

Calculate the average rate of change of bromate concentration between 0 and 50 seconds. Round your answer to two decimal places.
message_2:
To calculate the average rate of change of bromate concentration between 0 and 50 seconds, we will use the formula:

Average rate of change = (Change in concentration) / (Change in time)

From the data given, at t = 0 seconds, [BrO3] = 0.08 M, and at t = 50 seconds, [BrO3] = 0.12 M.

Change in concentration = Final concentration - Initial concentration
Change in concentration = 0.12 M - 0.08 M = 0.04 M

Change in time = 50 seconds - 0 seconds = 50 seconds

Now, we can calculate the average rate of change:

Average rate of change = (0.04 M) / (50 s)
Average rate of change = 0.0008 M/s

Rounded to two decimal places, the average rate of change of bromate concentration between 0 and 50 seconds is 0.00 M/s.
